item.title: CLEAR Sailing for 4G Wireless
item.description: You’re hearing a lot about 4G wireless technology, but did you know that CLEAR is already rolling out its 4G WiMAX network? If you happen to live in an area where CLEAR WiMAX is currently offered, you can experience internet speeds comparable to DSL or Cable, all without the need for physical wires. They have a range of plans to suit your needs, whether it’s for your home, mobile device, or both.

item.title: Cellular Netbooks Are Downright Cheap
item.description: Do you spend most of your computing time on the go? If so, a computer designed for mobility might be perfect for you, like one of the new netbooks with built-in 3G cellular internet access. You might be thinking laptops aren’t that bulky and work fine at a coffee shop. That’s true. A laptop with a wireless modem aircard would be comparable to a netbook in functionality. However, laptops are heavier and often carry unnecessary extras.

item.title: Internet Soothes The Savage Beasts
item.description: Instead of resorting to strict discipline, a school in Vail, Arizona, found a simple solution to improve student behavior on their buses: providing Wi-Fi access. Surprisingly, once installed, disruptive behavior vanished, and students became more engaged in their homework. This success story highlights a key point: providing Internet access can effectively address disciplinary issues. While students may engage in various online activities, the core issue of maintaining order is resolved.

item.title: Can You Get To The Cloud?
item.description: Cloud computing and storage are becoming increasingly popular, and many believe they will soon be the standard for computer use. There are many benefits to using the cloud, such as not needing to buy or maintain software, having data automatically backed up, accessing tools and data from anywhere on any device, and being able to use smaller, more portable computers, like netbooks, cellphones, and tablets. However, one concern remains: reliable access to the cloud.

item.title: 4G Wireless Quietly Encroaching on 3G
item.description: Cellular companies are promoting 3G wireless technology as the most advanced available. However, a faster technology called 4G is being gradually introduced across the country. This situation reflects the typical progression of technology, where an invention like wireless data service undergoes continuous advancements. Like early personal computers compared to today’s models, mobile data is following a similar path of growth. Cellular carriers dominate wide-area mobile service due to their extensive network infrastructure.

item.title: Business DSL Alternatives
The Next Decade of Bandwidth - Part III
item.description: A significant disagreement is occurring regarding the allocation of the electromagnetic spectrum. Wireless carriers and broadcasters, alongside government entities and satellite providers, are vying for their share. However, the spectrum is a finite resource. Although market forces like auctions and sales play a role, innovative solutions are crucial for optimizing spectrum utilization. One such innovation, inspired by the concept of “white space” in printing, targets unused portions of the spectrum. Just as blank areas exist on a printed page, gaps remain between allocated TV channels.

item.title: Is Dial-Up Internet Doomed?
item.description: Dial-up internet, once the king of online connectivity, is facing an uncertain future in a world dominated by broadband. With various technologies like WiFi, DSL, satellite, cable, fiber, and cellular competing for users, the relevance of the once-groundbreaking 56K dial-up is questionable. It might be surprising to learn that millions of people in the U.S. still use dial-up. These users fall into two groups: those who would switch to broadband if it were affordable and those who use the internet so infrequently that they prefer a free option.

item.title: T-Mobile 3G Aircard For PC and Mac
item.description: Want to connect your laptop to T-Mobile’s 3G network and get free access to their HotSpots? The T-Mobile webConnect USB Laptop Stick can make that happen. This device is a wireless modem with a USB connector that plugs into your PC or Mac. PCs require Windows XP or Vista, while Macs need OS X 10.3.9 or higher. This aircard provides internet access virtually anywhere in the U.S. with T-Mobile cellular coverage.

item.title: 4G WiMAX Wireless Broadband Available Now
item.description: Are you unhappy with your current internet options at home and on the go? Imagine a wireless internet service that works at your desk and travels with your laptop. What if this service was also cheaper than DSL, cable, and 3G wireless? What if it was incredibly fast? You should see if 4G WiMAX broadband is available in your area.
